<div>It had been a long four years, juggling football, a chemistry major, and my part-time job as a lab assistant, but the
hard work paid off. I was co-captain of the squad, the school’s all-time leading receiver, and an NCAA 1AA Academic All-American.
<div>Our season ended with an 8-3 record. A few pro scouts came to see me play. I ran the 40-yard dash and performed agility
drills for each one. The scouts came and went. My phone stayed silent. Was it the end of my football career?
Playing professional football is a long shot. There are approximately 70,000 college players in any given year. 1.6% go on
to play in the NFL. Those were my odds.
By April 30th I had taken my last final exam, was ready to graduate and pursue a future in science.
Around 11 p.m. that night, the phone rang in my dorm room. I picked up the receiver.
It was Joe Bushofsky, an NFL scout.
“You have been selected in the 11th round of the NFL college draft.”
I had made it to the NFL!
Four days later I was on a plane to Michigan with a dream of a career in the NFL.
